div.l: Nowe may I sey þat I am but an Ape
Yit hath my felowe sum what for his harme
He hathe the Millers doughter in his arme
And Auntrid him ⁊and hathe his nedes spedde
But y lye as a draf sakke in my bedde
And whan this Iape is tolde a noþer day
I shall be holde a daffe a Cokeney
I will arise and Aunter me be my faithe
Vnhardy vnsely as men seithe
And vp he risith and softely he wente
Vn to the Cradell and in his armes it hente
And bare it softely vn to his beddis fete
Sone after the wife hir routyngꝭe lete
And gan awake and wente hir͗e to pisse
And cam agayn̄ and gan here cradill mysse
And crepid and there couth she finde none
Allas qduod she y had almoste misgone
I hadde almoste gone to the Clerkis bedde
Ey bn̄enedicite than had I well spedde
And forthe she gothe till she the Cradill founde
She gropith alwey forthe with here honde
And founde the Clerkes bed ⁊and þought not but gode
Be cause that the Cradill by it stode
And wiste not where sche was for it was derke
And faire and well sche crepte yn to the clerke
And lieth full stille ⁊and wolde haue caught a slepe
With in a while this Iohn the Clerk vpp̄e lepte
On that gode wife and leide on soore
So mery a fitte she had not full yore
He prekid harde and depe as he wer͗e madde
Þis Ioly life þes two clerkꝭes had
Til that the thrid Cok began to singe
Aleyn̄ was alwery in the dawenyngꝭe
For he had swynkid alle the longꝭe nyght
And saide fare well malyn̄ my suete wight
Þe day is comen I may no leng̉er abide
But eủermore where so I go or ride
I am thin oune clerke so haue I hele
Nowe dere lemman qduod she go now fare wele
But er ye goo oon̄ thinge I will yow telle
Whan þu comest homward be the mell
Right atte entring of þe dore behinde
Þou shalt a cake of half a busshell find
